keyTakeAways: Tzachi Hanegbi has been fired by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as national security adviser, citing internal disagreements over military strategy in Gaza.
Gil Reich, the deputy head of the National Security Council, has been appointed as acting head of the NSC, signaling a shift in national security leadership.
Hanegbi publicly acknowledged responsibility for the failures that led to the October 7 Hamas attack, calling for a 'thorough investigation' to restore trust.

Netanyahu's government has not yet established a formal commission to investigate the October 7 attack, prompting criticism from opposition figures like Gadi Eisenkot, who accused the government of evading responsibility.
The decision reflects deep divisions within the Israeli government over the war in Gaza, particularly regarding the military takeover of Gaza City and the pursuit of a partial ceasefire with Hamas.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has dismissed national security adviser Tzachi Hanegbi, citing disagreements over military strategy in Gaza, particularly Hanegbi’s opposition to a full military takeover of Gaza City and his support for a partial deal with Hamas. Hanegbi acknowledged responsibility for failures leading to the October 7, 2023 Hamas attack and called for a thorough investigation, which Netanyahu’s government has yet to establish. As a result, deputy NSC head Gil Reich has been appointed as acting head of the National Security Council. The move underscores deep political divisions within Israel’s leadership and sparks criticism from opposition figures like Gadi Eisenkot, who accuse the government of evading accountability. The incident reflects broader tensions over national security policy, accountability for the October 7 attack, and the future direction of Israel’s war on Gaza.
title: Israel’s Netanyahu fires national security chief amid Gaza tensions
